'Methemoglobinemia' (or 'methaemoglobinaemia') is a disorder characterized by
the presence of a higher than normal level of methemoglobin (metHb, i.e., ferric
[Fe 3+ ] rather than ferrous [Fe 2+ ] haemoglobin) in the
blood. Methemoglobin is an oxidized form of hemoglobin that has an increased
affinity for oxygen and also results in an increased affinity of oxygen to the
three other heme sites (that are still ferrous) within the same tetrameric
hemoglobin unit. This leads to an overall reduced ability of the red blood cell
to release oxygen to tissues, with the associated oxygenâhemoglobin dissociation
curve therefore shifted to the left. When methemoglobin concentration is
elevated in red blood cells, tissue hypoxia can occur.
